subject: RE: [junit] Proposed parameterized test syntax for JUnit 4
msgSnippet: ... I d think that wether the Facade should be broken down is an orthogonal issue to wether the test class should be broken down into several classes. ... It
messageBody:
> Let me give an example. Imagine you have a statefull facade under
> test with has 5 methods: first one take no params, second - one param,
> third - two params, etc.
>
> Should we follow your rules and break this facade into 5 classes?
> Should we then write separate unit test class for each of those new
> classes?

I'd think that wether the Facade should be broken down is an orthogonal
issue to wether the test class should be broken down into several classes.


> The way I see it: there should be single test class with several
> parameterized test cases (so several parm generators) and test case
> would test a single test.

It seems to me that everyone understands that this is your position.

> I don't quite agree with this. Tests should be simple enough to
> require no refactorings at all. Applying OOP patters to the tests may
> lead to fragile test code that will require too much maintenance,
> especially if code under test is being structurally changed.

Is that your experience? Mine is quite the opposite: as with production
code, it is merciless refactoring that simplifies the test code to the point
that it becomes less fragile and reduces the amount of maintenance they
need.


> Can you then run ALL tests you found in a search view?
> Can these results guarantee that changed method under test didn't
> affected other methods and you don't have to run all tests for them
> too?

I don't think *any* approach can *guarantee* this.

The strategy I use is to seperate projects into modules which are highly
cohesive and typically small enough that running all of a single modules
tests isn't much of an issue.

>>>> To say that JUnit supports or doesn't support this way of
>>>> organizing tests sounds odd to me. I don't organize my tests a
>>>> certain way; I refactor the tests, and that's where they tend to
>>>> end up.
>>>
>>> By the way, I believe that such freely-organized test cases will
>>> be affected a lot when doing massive code refactorings and/or moving
>>> things around classses. So, I'd say it is always a tread off and has
>>> to be considered in a case by case base.

Why would that be the case???


>> You /believe/ this? or it's your experience? In my /experience/ it
>> just isn't that much of an issue.
>
> It could be not an issue for unit testing of the isolated classes,
> but it is quite different if those classes have more or less complex
> dependencies (e.g. those that may be injected by IoC container in real
> app, but mocked or stubbed in a test time). That perhaps problem with
> the toolset because such testing usually introduces lot of dynamic
> dependencies only resolved or even generated in the runtime.

I don't understand how this is affected by having one or more test case
classes per production class.

Confused, Ilja
